bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Rose Carter, Jr., June 3, 1900

div1.p: Carter writes that he has just finished an article on Havana yellow fever statistics. He gives his son academic advice.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Rose Carter, Jr., June 3, 1900
div1.opener:
C1
B29
Havana
June 3/00
Dear Henry:
div1.p:
I rec'd your watch yes-
terday. I am very much o-
bliged to you for the loan
of it. It has been beautifully
cleaned & looks a bright as
new. It brings back old
times to me, as it has been
with me in many a tough &
doubtful place. It has al-
ways been a lucky watch
too & I hope it may bring
me luck this time. Hope it may
help find the other one.

I have advertised for the other
one in the papers & have stuck
up a spanish notice “$40 00/100
& no questions asked” on my
room door- I have been to
C1
B28
2
the secret police, who have
my description & antecedents
all recorded, but who do not
seem to be specially interes-
ted in the thief. I am without
hope of finding it, unless the reor-
ganization of the secret police
should make them look for
it. For all of which I am very
sorry.

I have just finished, save the
posting in of footnotes, quite
a little piece on the y. f. sta-
tistics of Havana. I should not
have undertaken it with all the
other work I have on hand,
but I got interested in it &-well-
I am glad it is done.

Did you get the geometry prob-
lems I sent you? I did not work
3
3
them all, but all that I tried.
Where are you in your Geom-
etry? My calculation was that
by June 15, you would be near-
ly through; but I suppose you
lost some time on account
of having your teeth fixed.
If you finish it before schools
close it will be enough. By
the way, if you can manage
it, it would be a good thing
if you went down to Ashland
to see Sam's commencement.
I don't think you will enjoy
going: but you would enjoy
having gone & it would be
a good thing to see something of
college life.

I wish I were with you all at N. R.
4
now - soon it will be too hot
for comfort, & yet the best way
to s not to mind the heat is
to work in it in the beginning
of the summer.

I shall always be glad that I
was able to spend so much of the
winter at home as I did. It
was good for me - although my work
here did suffer in my absence.
I wish you all could come to Cuba,
just to see it. I don't think
you would like it much, & I
doubt if you would be well here
but I would like you to see the
country. A country around
Havana, of short, steep
hills - look like little
mountains & there are a
lot of little mountains
C1
B29
5
scattered about over the
island, as if shaken from a
dice-box - without any order
or reason for there arrange-
ment. The backbone of the
island is not a range of
mountains, as the map gives
it. It is a plane - nearly ab-
solutely barren. Mountains
all along the coast, on the
Western end & on the south
coast all the way- Indeed
all of the coast except from
Cardenas to Nueritas-
found these places on the map)
is mountainous & therefore
full of good harbors, some
as Cienfuegos & Havana, abso-
lutely land-locked - like lakes.
6
Almost. I had to send
I had to send one vessel
to Tortugas to be disinfec-
ted for plague - so that the
rats might not swim a-
shore.

Cherries should begin to be
ripening now - ripe good
in July, but it has been so
cool & pleasant here this week
that I expect you have had
weather too cool in Va.
div1.closer:
Your affec'ate
father H. R. Carter Tell your
Mother
that her plan
is all
for Florence
is all right
H. R. C.
How are the pecans back of
the house & in the hill to the
West of the house - they ripen in July
